Graphical abstract Recent progress to boost photoelectrochemical seawater oxidation was systemically reviewed based on based understanding of challenges, emphasizing the opportunities in material design, interfacial modification, local environment control, and reactor design. Photocatalytic water oxidation is a crucial counter-electrode reaction in the process of photoelectrochemical energy conversion. Despite its importance, challenges remain in effectively and sustainably converting water to oxygen, particularly with readily available and inexpensive electrolyte solutions such as seawater. While metal oxide materials have demonstrated their advantages in promoting efficiency by reducing overpotential and improving light utilization, stability remains limited by corrosion in multicomponent seawater. In this paper, we reviewed the relationship between four basic concepts including photoelectrochemistry, metal oxide, water oxidation and seawater to better understand the challenges and opportunities in photoelectrochemical (PEC) seawater oxidation. To overcome these challenges, the advances in material design, interfacial modification, local environment control and reactor design have been further reviewed to benefit the industrial PEC seawater oxidation. Noticeably, we demonstrate engineered layered metal oxide electrodes and cell structures that enable powerful and stable seawater oxidation. We also outline and advise on the future direction in this area. Keywords Photoelectrochemistry Anode Water oxidation Metal oxide Seawater Stability 1 Introduction The artificial production of highly valuable solar fuels such as hydrogen (H2) and hydrocarbons (C x H y O z ) represents a sustainable approach to meet the needs of the emerging low-carbon energy market [1,2]. In this context, photoelectrochemistry proves to be a promising way to achieve this goal [3,4]. However, the sluggish photoanodic reactions significantly limit the efficiency and stability of entire cell systems [4,5]. Despite significant advances, particularly in the synthesis of semiconductor materials such as metal oxides and their commendable performance in laboratory environments [6], one must be aware that experimental solutions often use highly pure water with replenished electrolytes [7,8]. This condition deviates substantially from the composition of real-world water sources. The resulting difference limits the practical application of photoelectrochemistry. Seawater, which covers 71% of the Earth’s surface, is a naturally occurring multicomponent electrolyte solution [9] and offers potential as a practical alternative [10]. However, the chlorine (Cl2) evolution often competes with oxygen (O2) evolution during the electrochemical and photoelectrochemical seawater oxidation, decreasing the efficiency of O2 and releasing harmful Cl2. Moreover, the stability of metal oxide electrodes is compromised in seawater environments and both the aggressive Cl− and Cl2 can affect the catalytic efficiency and stability by reconstructing the structure and surface solution environment [11]. Unfortunately, the crossover and corrosion of Cl composites seem inevitable during long-time catalytic reactions [12], raising the necessity of developing Cl-resistance systems. Additionally, other effects of the multicomponent seawater may also influence the efficiency and stability. Recently, numerous reviews have examined the influence of seawater on electrochemical applications and the use of metal oxides in photoelectrochemistry. Nevertheless, further investigations are essential to address stability concerns and facilitate the effective integration of photoelectrochemistry in seawater environments. In this review, we systematically summarize recent advances in photoelectrochemical (PEC) seawater oxidation, as shown in Fig. 1 . Starting from fundamental concepts, the discussion highlights metal oxides as the most promising materials for seawater oxidation. In addressing the challenges posed by multicomponent seawater, issues related to efficiency, selectivity, and multiple stability are highlighted. To address these challenges, this review presents recent advances in material science, engineering design, and seawater utilization reactor systems to solve the problem of photoelectron utilization and interface mass exchange. Finally, the review concludes with a discussion of these strategies and provides an outlook on the future industrialization of seawater oxidation. 2 Concepts and challenges PEC seawater oxidation with metal oxide materials is a composite concept that includes the PEC method, metal oxide materials, water oxidation reaction and targeted seawater oxidation. Understanding the connections between these basic concepts, as shown in Fig. 2 (a), is critical to gaining insight into the challenges facing this area. In short, the PEC oxidation reactions of water and seawater exhibit similar photocorrosion but have differences in efficiency, selectivity and chemical stability, clearly showing the challenges in PEC seawater oxidation. 2.1 PEC based on metal oxides The PEC process begins with the generation of hole-electron pairs through photon excitation, as shown in Fig. 2(b). Generally, when photons excite electrons, they can cross the band gap, resulting in the formation of holes in the valence band (VB). These spatially separated holes and electrons can accumulate on specific energy bands or surface states of the material interface and lead to photocorrosion. Therefore, many researchers are dedicated to developing advanced materials to mitigate photocorrosion effects. To date, more than 200 semiconductors have been studied, either through experimental or theoretical approaches, as shown in Fig. 2(c) [13]. Although single crystals [14] are suitable for photoelectrochemistry, only metal oxides have demonstrated photostability in water oxidation. In particular, it is hypothesized that only semiconductors with a bandgap greater than 2.48 eV exhibit chemical stability without the need for passivation layers during water oxidation. As a result, 52 semiconductors meet this criterion and require further investigation. It is noteworthy that almost all of these semiconductors are metal oxides. To achieve acceptable solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency and stability, some typical metal oxide semiconductors are investigated, as depicted in Fig. 2(d) [15]. 2.2 PEC water oxidation After generating excited electron-hole pairs, holes that can overcome recombination move from the VB to the surface for the reaction. To satisfy thermodynamics, the VB position must exceed the standard potential of H2O/O2 (also listed in Fig. 2b with details in Eq. (1)) during the reacting process; otherwise, oxidation may occur before the hole enters the water, resulting in chemical corrosion rather than water oxidation. Alternatively, if the surface is passivated, under high bias conditions, holes can migrate to the surface and catalyze water decomposition. (1) 2H2O − 4e− = O2 + 4H+, E 0 = +1.23 V vs. RHE (2) 2H2O − 2e− = H2O2 + 2H+, E 0 = +1.76 V vs. RHE (3) 2Cl− − 2e− = Cl2, E 0 = +1.36 V vs. RHE In practice, it is often a challenge for metal-oxide materials in photoelectrochemical (PEC) processes that the STH efficiency exceeds 3% (1% in photocatalysis), well below the efficiency threshold required for commercial viability lies. These performance limitations are primarily due to the dynamic mismatch between the lifetime of bulk charge carriers and the timescale of interfacial catalysis, which leads to the recombination of most photo-excited electrons and holes. Addressing these underlying challenges therefore primarily focuses on material design strategies aimed at improving charge separation, improving bulk charge transfer dynamics, optimizing charge distribution, and increasing catalysis rates [16]. For a long time, the four-electron oxygen evolution reaction (OER) was considered the main reaction, while two-electron products such as H2O2 (Eq. (2)) were often considered intermediate or side products. Some research started to address the selectivity of oxygen evolution and efforts are being made on material and cell design. For example, Choi's group developed surface P-treated Mo-doped BiVO4 for 100-h H2O2 production with anthraquinone-anchored carbon nanotube counter and the optimized Faraday efficiencies (FEs) reached 43% and 100% for anode and cathode [17]. They also developed TiO2 nanorods/RuO x in an electrolyte-free aqueous system without bias [18]. Li et al. [19] identified that FTO/Bi2WO6:Mo achieves a peak FE of about 79% at 3.2 V vs. RHE. An et al. [20] employed BiVO4/SrTiO3/CaSnO3 for FEH2O2 of 90% in a 144 cm2 array panel reactor. The mechanisms are still controversial. Tachikawa's group found that segregation of binary dopants can enable hematite-based heterostructures for solar H2O2 synthesis, and Sn/Ti-doped hematite mesocrystals achieved 0.8 μmol min−1 cm−2 with 90% selectivity for the PEC-H2O2 production [21]. Wan et al. [22] suggested that the wettability of N2-treated BiVO4 should be the key to the kinetic control of H2O2 production and contribute to the best FEH2O2 of 81.2%. Zhang et al. [23] demonstrated that crystal facets can affect band bending and provide a deep valence band level to produce H2O2 with an FE of 70%. It is interesting to understand PEC-H2O2 production, but there is still a long way to go to fully understand the entire process. Here, we simply maintain another point that metal peroxide could be an intermediate for the OER and set PEC-OER as the target for review [24]. The *OOH adsorbed species are formed on the surface (Eqs. (4)–(7)) and sequentially undergo the OER process (Eq. (8)). (4) H2O − e− ↔ *OH + H+, E 0 = +2.38 V vs. RHE (5) *OH − e− ↔ *=O + H+ (6) *=O + H2O − e− ↔ *OOH + H+ (7) *OOH − e− ↔ O2 + H+ (8) H2O2 − 2e− ↔ O2 + 2H+, E 0 = +0.68 V vs. RHE 2.3 OER reactions in water or seawater Electrochemical and photoelectrochemical reactions including OER reactions are based on supporting electrolyte solutions that transport charges via ions to the counter electrodes. In the laboratory, the electrolytes are obtained by adding acid, alkali, or salt to the precious fresh water (Fig. 3 a). Buffer solutions such as NaHCO3, Na3BO3, and Na2HPO4 are also sometimes added to maintain the local pH. Although the composition of seawater varies in different regions, the main components are generally stable. To conduct OER experiments in seawater, it is necessary to first understand the key differences between seawater and common experimental electrolytes. Unlike the ultrapure or distilled water in the laboratory, seawater is naturally multicomponent [9] and its common components are shown in Fig. 3(b). Although the proportion of impurities in seawater is only about 3.5%, they can significantly change the physico-chemical properties of the water. Many researchers have discussed the challenges of electrochemical OER in seawater. These challenges [5] can be summarized in four main points (Fig. 3c). Firstly, the weight of sodium halide including NaCl in 100 g of seawater can reach 3 g, which refers to a Cl− anion concentration of 0.5 mol L−1. This concentration can induce serve Cl2 evolution reactions (ClERs, Eq. (3)) [25] and cause pitting of chloride species, which significantly affects both OER selectivity and anode stability. Secondly, cations such as Ca2+ and Mg2+ can penetrate the electrode or form non-conductive deposits, leading to deactivation of the anode. Thirdly, microplastics or microorganisms can be absorbed or grown on the electrode; these impurities can affect the conductivity and corrode the electrodes. Fourthly, the lack of buffers can lead to large pH fluctuations (Eq. (1)) and the unexpected accumulation of excessive proton or hydroxide ions can attack the active sites. To overcome these challenges, electrode and reactor designs appear to be necessary, which we will discuss in the next sections. 2.4 Metal oxides in seawater In addition to their function as photoelectron generators, metal oxides also play the role of cocatalysts, providing active centers and direct contact with seawater. Noble metal oxides like IrO2 and RuO2 have been largely researched as possible OER anodes and highly dispersed ones can contribute to good performance [26–28]. Yuan et al. implanted fully dispersed IrO x on Fe2O3 and achieved a photocurrent of 1.35 mA cm−2, as shown in Fig. 4 (a) [29]. These noble metal oxides generally have high stability and can even be used for ClERs on dimensionally-stable-anode (DSA)-type electrodes (Fig. 4b) [30,31]. Notably, noble metal oxides are precious and expensive, making the development of earth-abundant metal hydroxides like CoOOH, FeOOH, and NiOOH essential. During these years, these metal hydroxides have been systemically studied as electrocatalysts [32,33]. Generally, they are reconstructed on the surface of metal or metal oxides. After formation, metal hydroxides such as CoOOH or FeOOH are amorphous layers with different chemical bridges to the substrate [34,35]. During this catalytic process, photogenerated holes can be transferred to CoOOH or FeOOH, resulting in a valence change of cobalt ions to achieve efficient water oxidation. However, unlike noble metal oxides, these transient metal hydroxides are unstable in seawater due to chemical corrosion (Fig. 4d and e). For example, experimental and simulated findings demonstrate that Cl− tends to corrode locally, leading to the formation of narrow-deep pits, whereas Br− exhibits extensive etching leading to the generation of shallow-wide pits. This behavior can be attributed to the fast diffusion kinetics of Cl− and the lower reaction energy of Br− within the passivation layer [11]. Despite the weak stability, these metal oxide catalysts may have functioned as cocatalysts due to their advantages in charge transfer and active site provision, thus providing the opportunity for highly efficient PEC seawater oxidation. 2.5 Challenges in PEC seawater oxidation with metal oxide materials At the end of this part of the concept and challenges, we are trying to conclude the challenges in PEC seawater oxidation with metal oxides by expanding the understanding of the challenges in PEC water oxidation. Here, the PEC seawater oxidation, to which we focus, refers to the PEC water oxidation in seawater, instead of other side reactions. Firstly, reducing overpotential and improving photocurrent by optimizing the material and electrode structure is still essential for achieving low-energy consumption water oxidation. To achieve this goal, studies are needed to develop metal oxide electrodes with longer charge lifetime, higher electron transfer rate and higher catalytic performance. Secondly, the existence of anions such as Cl− in seawater poses new challenges in selectivity. Although OER has a lower thermodynamic potential than ClER, the 4-electron-involved process can make OER more difficult than two-electron-involved ClER. Notably, ClER involves no proton, while OER involves four protons, suggesting a higher pH favorable for OER. However, seawater appears to be neutral, making it difficult to design interfaces and battery structures to create the right local environment. Thirdly, corrosion is the biggest enemy of stability. Photocorrosion and chemical corrosion are the two main types of corrosion during the PEC water oxidation process. Photocorrosion occurs due to the accumulation of holes and electrons on the surface and requires the development of highly conductive semiconductors and good hole-extracting centers. It occurs when the semiconductor generates excessive photo-electrons/holes. To solve this problem, we need to better understand the physicochemical properties of materials for targeted designs. More importantly, the design of carrier collectors or extractors is very important to prevent photocorrosion. Chemical corrosion occurs through the interaction between catalytic materials and solutions. In detail, chemical corrosion can occur during the catalysis process if the metal-involved intermediate is easily soluble or desorbed, without recovering for the catalytic cycle. Therefore, establishing a sustainable cycle in the system design can benefit the PEC catalytic cycle. Fourth, the exposure to cations and microorganisms should also be taken into account in practical seawater oxidation. However, most wide bandgap semiconductors can self-heal after reactions and the rapid OER process can generate O2 to remove the microorganic from the top surface. Meanwhile, the electric field between two electrodes can repel cations from the photoanode. Therefore, we will mainly discuss the solutions to the first three challenges. 3 Designs and opportunities 3.1 Material design of substrate metal oxides Metal oxides are considered important substrates for the deposition of active sites for water oxidation [36]. Here we use the best of these metal oxides including TiO2, ZnO, Fe2O3, BiVO4, and WO3 as a reference to understand the design ideas. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) was first described for photoelectrochemical water splitting by Fujishima and Honda [37] in 1972. To date, four TiO2 phases (three of which are listed in Fig. 5 a) have been reported for PEC water oxidation: anatase (I41/amd), rutile (P42/mnm), brookite (Pcab), and amorphous [38]. Rutile is the thermodynamically stable phase in nature and experimentally showed a bandgap of 3.0 eV with a charge carrier lifetime of 20 ms [39], which is better than anatase when using photoholes. However, it can only use UV light, which only makes up a small portion of the sun’s energy. Meanwhile, the lower charge mobility of rutile TiO2 is related to its low conductivity and requires strategies to reduce the size and create a second center for transport. Remarkably, anatase can become the most stable phase when the size of TiO2 decreases to less than 30 nm. In addition, almost all elements were tested to break the symmetry of TiO2 to extend its absorption edge to the visible light part and improve the charge mobility. For example, colored or black TiO2 [40] can be obtained by treatment with H2, Ar, or other elements and the photoelectrochemical properties have been reported to be improved [41]. In contrast to the first two types, amorphous TiO2 was viewed as a passivation layer without a concrete band structure due to its possible wide bandgap. Another TiO2 could be brookite which is difficult to synthesize, and it has also been used for photoelectrochemistry [42]. The trend in TiO2 research has recently gone in three directions: firstly, it is about combining different phases of TiO2. Commercial P25 (anatase: rutile = 3:1) showing better performance than either single one is a success [43]. The combined structure can increase in anatase holes observed from the microsecond in Fig. 5(b) [39]. Another example: Kang et al. [44] found that stable Ov-induced amorphous domains in TiO2 with improved catalytic performances represent a scalable strategy for practical Ov engineering in functional metal oxides. Second, regulating the electronic and morphological structure can improve charge transfer and light utilization. Nanostructured TiO2 has been widely used as a substrate to enhance the reaction efficiency [45]. Zhan et al. [46] found that the photoetched Ar+-treated TiO2 exhibits a nano-groove pattern for enhanced PEC performance, as shown in Fig. 5(c). Meanwhile, heterodoped atoms such as B3+, I7+, S4+/S6+, and P5+ can act as electron donors or trapping sites, facilitating the separation of charge carriers and suppressing the recombination of electron-hole pairs [47]. Based on the Ti-O structure, other stable phases such as SrTiO3 and CaTiO3 are also formed. For example, the presence of Sr causes SrTiO3 to exhibit better charge transfer than TiO2 during water oxidation [48]. CaTiO3 can form on top of TiO2 with an adapted lattice for oxygen evolution in Fig. 5(d) [49]. Thirdly, combining TiO2 with dyes or plasmons can enlarge the absorbed light spectra. For instance, Zhu et al. [50] developed a pyridyl anchor for Ru molecular modified TiO2 nanoparticle (Fig. 5e) and it was demonstrated that the anchoring ligands have a monomer structure responding for stable photocurrents of up to 1.7 mA cm−2 with an optimized efficiency of 1.5%. Compared to the prominent role of TiO2 in photocatalysis, zinc oxide (ZnO) appears to have limitations due to its instability. ZnO can crystallize into two primary forms for PEC water oxidation [51]: hexagonal wurtzite and cubic zincblende in Fig. 6 (a). While hexagonal wurtzite is more common and thermodynamically more stable, cubic structures can also be cultivated under certain conditions [52]. Although the bandgap of ZnO is over 3.0 eV which is similar to that of TiO2, its structure is both tetrahedral and octahedral. By adjusting the concentration of oxygen vacancies and zinc interstitials [53], it is possible to adjust the bandgap of p-type ZnO and thereby modify its absorption edge, as shown in Fig. 6(b). This tunability allows the photocatalytic performance of ZnO to be optimized for specific applications by tailoring its absorption spectrum to the desired light wavelengths for catalytic reactions [54]. However, chemical corrosions of ZnO under acid or alkaline conditions limit ZnO's further development in PEC. Studies on bismuth vanadate (BiVO4) for solar water oxidation began in the 1990s [55]. The visible-response BiVO4 shows a bandgap of 2.4 eV, which originates from the transmission from Bi 6s to V 3d [56]. As early as 2012, Luo et al. [57] began to study BiVO4 for PEC seawater oxidation, thereby proving its potential. Although the first nanocrystalline BiVO4 film photoelectrode was synthesized by spin coating in 2003, its incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency (IPCE) was limited to 29% at 420 nm [58]. Strong recombination and sluggish water oxidation were considered to be the two main reasons for the limited performance. The serious charge recombination in both bulk and surface was then reported as the main limit for charge transport and transfer, which can be confirmed by adding SO3 2− or methanol to the solution. The calculated charge transport properties are modest, at most a hole diffusion length (L p) of ∼70 nm [59]. Typical ideas to overcome this problem include extending the charge lifetime through doping, creating vacancies, and shortening the transport distance by limiting the crystal size [60–64]. To overcome the sluggish oxidation kinetics, efficient junctional structures and cocatalysts have been developed. The high-performance BiVO4 was reported in 2014 by combining the nanoporous structure with Fe/Ni-OOH for stable water oxidation [65]. Since then, many different extrinsic modification strategies have been developed to improve efficiency and stability [66], and Kim et al. [67] have systemically reviewed the advances before 2019. The application of WO3 films as a photoanode for water photoelectrooxidation was first reported by Hodes and co-workers in 1976 [68]. Since then, numerous experimental and theoretical researches have been conducted. In general, WO3 has a bandgap of appropriately 2.7 eV and the VB at 3 V (pH 7), which is suitable for visible-light-driven OER. The diffusion length can reach 150 nm [69] with electron mobility of 12 cm2 V−1 s−1 [70], which is higher than most metal oxide semiconductors. Though bare WO3 is stable in acids, the intermediates from selected electrolytes may react with the WO3 and cause photocorrosion (Fig. 7 a) [71]. Mascaro group [72] has comprehensively reviewed defect engineering based on oxygen vacancies, doping, decorations, and homo and heterojunctions for improving the efficiency of WO3. These methods are still studied to enhance the performance of WO3. For example, Shao et al. [73] developed a two-step flame heating approach for engineering tunable bulk and surface vacancy, achieving a 10 times high PEC performance (Fig. 7b). WO3 with oxygen vacancy can be used to fabricate bio-photoelectrochemical cells [74], outputting an open circuit of 0.81 V. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) in Fig. 7(c) indicated the different surface chemical states of pristine WO3 and WO3− x nanorods in the cells. Moreover, Yang et al. [75] reported a WO3 (002)/m-WO3 homojunction film (Fig. 7d) that is composed of an upper WO3 layer with predominant (002) facet (WO3 (002)) and a lower WO3 layer with multi-crystal facets (m-WO3) as a photoanode for superior activity in the adsorption and activation of water molecules during solar water oxidation. Noticeably, Li et al. [76] fabricated highly porous WO3 on FTO which possesses a 0.76 V anodic potential in synthetic seawater. This directly proves the validity of WO3′s application in water. As hematite, Fe2O3 has a band gap of about 2.0 eV, indicating a limiting current density of 12.6 mA cm−2. Its common crystal phases include alpha (α), gamma (γ), and beta (β) (Fig. 8 a) [77]. Among them, α-Fe2O3 has been extensively studied as an excellent photoanode since the first attempt to use Fe2O3 in water photolysis. A good overview of the early efforts was given by Sivula et al. [78]. In general, five challenges and possible solutions were proposed in the early studies including the low flat band potential that can be overcome by providing an external bias voltage, the large required overpotential that can be solved by increasing the external bias voltage and the relatively low absorption coefficient. It was confirmed that the size is smaller than 120 nm instead of 500 nm, the conductivity of the majority requires a high degree of doping, and the diffusion length is only 2–4 nm short, which could be solved by optimizing the electrode morphology. As a result, though nanostructured Fe2O3 with current density of more than 2.2 mA cm−2 was reported by Kay et al. [79] (Fig. 8b), the benchmark current density (Fig. 8c) is still difficult to break 5 mA cm−2 [80]. Meanwhile, the development of β-Fe2O3 is rapid. Sn-doped β-Fe2O3 (Fig. 8d) was found to be able to hinder the transfer of protons to lattice oxygen, thereby preventing excessive surface hydration and Cl ion coordination [81]. Although β-Fe2O3 could transform into α-Fe2O3 due to its metastable nature, it can be further stabilized by Zr-doping for improved PEC-OER as reported by Zhang et al. (Fig. 8e) [82]. Thus, the stable OER (Fig. 8f) can be obtained with the release of stoichiometric H2 and O2 (Fig. 8g). In this part, we reviewed the advances in material science and largely solved many challenges of charge separation and transfer, thereby increasing efficiency. Typically, nanostructures and dopants can improve the conductivity of major charge carriers and maintain the instinctive transfer length, and junction structures or additional photovoltaic (PV) devices can help adjust the band position. In addition, some researchers have started to focus on the stability of metal oxides, especially in the application of seawater oxidation. The influence of surface hydroxides and other anions was also been taken into consideration. However, this is just the beginning of the long road to stable seawater oxidation. 3.2 Interfacial modification Interfacial modification is a comprehensive concept with various types including overcoating nanoparticle modification, molecular immobilization, etc. A state-to-art PEC water oxidation aims to achieve three important effects: Firstly, a compact or semipermeable layer is required that can protect the substrate from corrosion. This layer can be either organic or inorganic and protects the light adsorption substrate from the electrolyte. Secondly, the electron transmitter or hole collector is useful to accelerate charge transfer across the passivation layer. Thirdly, active sites are key to hole consumption for water oxidation. To date, most efforts on interfacial modification have been devoted to the design of cocatalysts. Various nanostructured cocatalysts including noble/transition metal oxides and complexes have been developed to further improve efficiency [83,84]. They are originally designed to provide active sites for the reactions. In most cases, electrochemical catalysts can be used in the PEC reactions after proper modification. For example, IrO x and Ir complexes have been modified on TiO2 and BiVO4 [26,85], and only those monomers and nanoparticles modified on the top can promote water oxidation and avoid the shortcut between substrate and electrolyte (Fig. 9 a). Other noble metal derivatives like Ru oxides and complexes are also workable in a wide pH range [50,86–88]. As reported by Zhao et al., Ru on TiO substrates can work at different pHs with the lowest overpotential at acids (Fig. 9b). The derivatives from Co, Ni, and Fe are also popular under mild or alkaline conditions. Nanostructured MBi and MPi (M = Fe, Co, Ni) can act as cocatalysts in borate (Bi) or phosphate (Pi), while MOOH is useful at high pH. They can not only provide active centers but also improve charge transfer. For example, Xue et al. [89] reported that nanostructured CoBi can benefit charge transfer in Bi (Fig. 9c). Lu et al. [90] obtained 4.5 mA cm−2 at 1.23 vs. RHE by modifying CoBi on bismuth vacancy-engineered BiVO4 photoanode. FeBi [91,92] and NiBi [93,94] were also studied, which benefited the efficiency and stability of metal oxide semiconductors. As further examples, Ren et al. [34] reported that a CoOOH nanolayer can be formed through morphological development (Fig. 9d), which increases the photocurrent of TiO2 to 1.3 mA cm−2 with an IPCE of 56.2% at 365 nm. Wang et al. [95] prepared ultrathin CoOOH nanosheets on Fe2O3 by the transformation of [Co-EDTA]2− species (Fig. 9e) and achieved 2.8 times higher photocurrent density than pure Fe2O3. In addition, M-MOFs are also a hot topic these days. For example, Pan et al. [96] developed self-assembled NiFe-MOFs to promote the OER property of Ov-BiVO4. Overall, loading semiconductors with oxidation cocatalysts can facilitate OER by providing the active/reaction sites while suppressing charge recombination and reverse reactions (Fig. 9f) [97]. This promotes quantum efficiency and photostability through rapid charge exchange. Except for the active sites in contact with the electrolyte, a large area of photoanode without active sites is also exposed to the electrolyte. Therefore, the stability of the photoanodes involves both the constant catalytic cycle and the passivated surface. Many metal oxides have been deposited by atomic layer deposition, sputtering, electrochemical deposition, and so on, contributing to the core-shell structures [98]. For example, Lei et al. [99] developed an ALD-derived NiO x catalyst layer on BiVO4 to suppress the V5+ dissolution (Fig. 10 a), achieving a record stability of over 2100 h. Zhao’s group proposed that sandwiched ALD-TiO2 can enhance the stability of BiVO4 [85,89]. Zhang et al. [100] used ALD-Al2O3 as the hole tunneling structure for Sn-Fe2O3 (Fig. 10b). Hou et al. [101] deposited V2O5 on ZnO nanorod arrays by radio frequency magnetron sputtering (Fig. 10c), enhancing the photocurrent from 0.42 to 1.21 mA cm−2. He et al. [102] photothermally deposited a Co3O4 layer between BiVO4 and Fe/NiOOH, engineering high-performance water oxidation. Liu et al. [103] used vacancy-rich VO x through a photo-assisted electrodeposition process to modify BiVO4, benefiting the adsorption of water molecules and creating the interfacial charge flow highway to promote charge transfer. Zhang et al. [104] modified hematite with a gradient tantalum doped shell by a combination of hydrothermal regrowth strategy and hybrid microwave annealing, establishing a passivation and built-in electric field layer for efficient charge transfer. Dhandole et al. [105] spin-coated a ZrO2 passivation layer to suppress the charge recombination of self-motivated thermally oxidized Fe2O3 nanoflake photoanode. Though these passivation layers have been developed for PEC OER, their performance in PEC seawater oxidation is still confusing. Moreover, Zhao et al. [106] used S/N doped carbon dots to repulse Cl− on TiO2 in seawater, limiting the ClER. The most special part of the photoanode is the electron transmitter or hole collector (Fig. 11 a), which explains how the electrons/holes leave/reach the surface with limited recombination [107,108]. This process takes place on the surface in a range of approximately several micrometers (Fig. 11b) [109]. Junction engineering in semiconductor science can help us better understand the process. These junctions can be metal-semiconductor junctions, semiconductor-semiconductor junctions, or even metal-insulator-semiconductor-type junctions (MIS). For example, Jiang et al. [110] used Au nanoparticles (NPs) as a bridge between BiVO4 and Co4O4 molecules. Here, the heavy metal Au NPs acted both as a collector of holes from the BiVO4 semiconductor and as a binding site for molecules (Fig. 11c), resulting in an increased photocurrent density of over 5 mA cm−2. Liu et al. [111] spin-coated a hole transport layer made of CuSCN (Fig. 11d), which significantly increased the charge transport efficiency. The semiconductor-semiconductor junction between BiVO4 and CuSCN appears to be the key to the improved performance. A similar example is the junction between Fe2O3 or In2O3 and MFe2O4 (M = Zn, Ca, etc.) in Fig. 11(e) [112,113]. Apparently, in most papers, the charge extractors are composed of cocatalysts or compact layers, so their importance can be easily ignored. However, an efficient photoanode requires a junction structure to extract the holes from the substance for further water oxidation. Although these three modification parts are independent of each other, the boundary between these three effects seems to be ambiguous. A simple example is that M1M2-OOH can simultaneously play the three roles in a system. For example, Laskowski et al. [114] proposed Ni(Fe)O x H y and CoO x H y overlayers can be the passivation layer with catalytic surface and provide the junction for hole collection. This may help explain why the M-OOH overlayers are so efficient in photoanodic systems. The idea was also proposed by Ning et al. [115] that transition-metal hydroxides exhibited good hole transfer properties for PEC OER. Liu et al. [116] has proven that FeNiOOH can exceed the limit of the proton transfer and thus improve the OER property. Although the actual structures and effects of the M-OOH overlayers are still a mystery and require more effort to explore, we believe in their essential role in the final functions of passivating the interface, transferring the charge and catalyzing the OER reaction. 3.3 Local environment control In recent decades, most studies have focused on achieving high efficiency and selectivity, but few studies have begun to focus on the photocatalytic process during water oxidation. In PEC seawater oxidation, the catalytic process becomes more important due to the existence of various ions. In this part, we will look at verifying the modification of catalysts in a controlled local environment. Firstly, we should note that catalysts are dynamically stable during the catalytic process, not static. In most cases, we only know the states of catalysts before and after and not during the reactions. In philosophy, we can think of this as a question of the ship of Theseus. This change can occur in both solid and liquid. The Bi/V ratio can influence the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio in FeOOH and contribute to a changed open-circuit voltage [35]. When a small amount of Ni2+ was added to the electrolyte (Fig. 12 a), the PEC-OER system of BiVO4 could reach a new equilibrium, as reported by Kuang et al. [117]. Trace amounts of NaVO3 in the electrolyte would suppress V5+ dissolution and increase stability to over 2100 h (Fig. 12b), as Lei et al. confirmed [99]. Therefore, trace additives can affect the local environment, thereby promoting efficiency and stability. Secondly, though PEC seawater oxidation is a systemic process, the final catalysis occurs on the interface, determining the importance of interfacial property in the hole consumption. For seawater oxidation, both hydroxide ions and water molecules can be reactants for OER through the inner sphere charge transfer process. Moreover, the Cl− is expected to keep away from the structure, or ClER would be the main process. Yang et al. [75] reported that the (002) facet of WO3 can provide a more hydrophilic surface, contributing to the adsorption and activation of water. In contrast, Jadwiszczak et al. [76] found 70% FECl2 on FTO/WO3 with a limiting current density of 5 mA cm−2. Therefore, the adoption of OH− and H2O should directly affect the reactions. Moreover, this effect can also be extended so that the adsorbed ions or molecules may also change the interfacial polarization. Ma et al. [118] reported the polarized TiO2 photoanode obtained via –OH moiety decoration (Fig. 12c), leading to a charge separation efficiency of 94% at 1.23 vs. RHE. Li et al. [119] present electrolyte-assisted charge polarization over an N-doped TiO2 photocatalyst (Fig. 12d), which demonstrates the stoichiometric evolution of H2 and O2 from the thermo-assisted photocatalytic splitting of seawater. Their results show that ionic species in seawater can be selectively adsorbed on photo-polarized facets of the opposite charge, which can prolong the charge-carrier lifetime by a factor of five, leading to an overall energy conversion efficiency of 15.9% ± 0.4% at 270 °C. Furthermore, Guo et al. [120] have developed a catalyst with controlled Lewis acid sites for direct seawater electrolysis, giving a possible new avenue to design the catalysts with a controlled local environment. Thirdly, the OER is a four-hole involved reaction, making it hard to infer the right reaction pathway. When the OER occurs, the local pH value will change a lot, leading to the different stability of metal-oxide intermediates. This brings controversy in the key intermediates during OER. For example, Wang et al. [121] identified symmetric FeO6 in Ferrihydrite as the key to accepting photogenerated holes (Fig. 12e). Miao et al. [122] confirmed the existence of [FeCl4] units with Mössbauer spectra (Fig. 12f) and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) spectra (Fig. 12g), which have the activity for OER. Therefore, more in situ spectroscopic methods are crucial for characterizing key intermediates. 3.4 Reactor design Scaled-up industrial water electrolysis equipment that can be used with abundant seawater is key for affordable hydrogen production [2]. The search for highly stable, dynamic, and economical electrocatalysts could have a significant impact. All conditions that have been reported have been listed in Table 1 . However, there is still a gap between the experimental and industrial conditions. Here, a direct way to overcome such a barrier relies on the design of the reactor [123]. In an ideal seawater splitting system (Fig. 13 ), four parts including seawater exchange device, photoanodic cell, counter hydrogen evolution and collection device and ion exchange membrane are essential due to the multicomponent property of seawater. The purpose of the seawater exchange device is to achieve continuous use of seawater, and its function is to preliminarily purify seawater and isolate impurities such as microorganisms and microplastics. It is also possible to equip an ion exchange membrane in this device, but additional electrolytes should be readded, enhancing the cost. For the other three parts, the photoanode and cathode would be separated by membrane [124] to prevent the mass exchange between the photoanodic and photocathodic systems. Because almost no latest research has yet been found, we can just establish a proper model as follows. During seawater oxidation, both O2/Cl2 and H2 could be extracted and collected, along with highly concentrated NaOH for sequentially selective water oxidation with hindered ClER. This cycle can then be sustained, paving the way for stable seawater oxidation. 4 Summary In summary, we have reviewed recent advances in photoelectrochemical seawater oxidation. Given the challenges and concepts, we tried to find a possible way to realize industrial seawater oxidation from the aspects of material design, interface modification and local environmental control. Furthermore, we see a possible cycle in the design of the reactor. The focus of our research article is to find efficient and stable photoelectrocatalytic seawater oxidation at multiple levels, ranging from the inner to outer. (1) Regarding the challenge of the limited efficiency and photocorrosion in materials, we reviewed the advances in PEC water oxidation. We believe that the further development of novel oxide materials remains of paramount importance to advance the field of photoelectrochemical seawater oxidation. These materials can come from either doping existing substrates or optimizing novel structural frameworks. Such innovations provide the opportunity to further improve light absorption and transmission, thereby increasing overall efficiency. (2) Regarding the challenge of chemical corrosion due to the multicomponent property of seawater, the progress of interface modification was discussed. Our goal is to protect both catalytic and noncatalytic interfaces simultaneously, ensuring electrode structural integrity, efficient carrier transport, and increased catalytic performance at active sites. (3) The challenge from the interactions between metal oxides and electrolytes was also important. Throughout the catalytic process, the microenvironment at the semiconductor-electrolyte interface is a critical factor in the stability and effectiveness of catalytic reactions. Particularly in seawater, the concentration of chlorine and bromine species as well as their dynamic interaction with reaction intermediates and electrode materials have a major influence on catalytic activity and stability. Therefore, we reviewed three methods, that is additive, interfacial acid sites and in situ detection, to understand and solve such problem. These methods will bring opportunities in better design of the photoanodic system. (4) Scaling systems for industrial applications represent an indispensable aspect of the industrialization process, which is challenging. Reactor design, an integral part of photoelectrochemical seawater oxidation, serves as a key approach to addressing various challenges. Even if comprehensive seawater purification, such as desalination, may not be necessary, the inclusion of simpler cleaning mechanisms such as filters for removing insoluble impurities is essential. In addition, the strategic reactor design facilitates the comprehensive recycling of seawater, a crucial aspect of sustainable operations. Despite the limited number of related studies, we remain confident that the reaction framework described here lays the foundation for a viable route to the industrialization of photoelectrochemical seawater oxidation. 5 Outlook Looking forward, the key areas we have fully explored still require targeted research and development to advance the field of PEC seawater oxidation and facilitate industrial application. (1) The development of novel metal oxide pigments can provide new opportunities for high PEC performance with low photocorrosion in seawater. These metal oxides can be either organic or inorganic, either perovskite or spinel, even either crystalline or amorphous. (2) Advanced technologies are required in the field of interfacial layer fabrication, including atomic layer deposition, self-assembly, etc. These technologies can support the precise fabrication of passivation layers and cocatalysts. Precise structures will further improve understanding of the precise functions of each component in seawater at the atomic level. (3) More in situ technologies such as Raman, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD) are required to understand the interaction between photoanodes and electrolytes, which is the ship of Theseus in PEC seawater oxidation. They will initially solve the problem of how to design an efficient and stable photoanode. (4) Industrial application is the ideal goal of scientific research. The engineered reactor design will further promote the in-depth study of photoelectrochemical engineering and ultimately provide the ultimate guarantee for the design of scaled-up reactors that can be applied in practice. From this perspective, we believe that PEC seawater oxidation can satisfy the future energy market. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic water oxidation is a crucial counter-electrode reaction in the process of photoelectrochemical energy conversion. Despite its importance, challenges remain in effectively and sustainably converting water to oxygen, particularly with readily available and inexpensive electrolyte solutions such as seawater. While metal oxide materials have demonstrated their advantages in promoting efficiency by reducing overpotential and improving light utilization, stability remains limited by corrosion in multicomponent seawater. In this paper, we reviewed the relationship between four basic concepts including photoelectrochemistry, metal oxide, water oxidation and seawater to better understand the challenges and opportunities in photoelectrochemical (PEC) seawater oxidation. To overcome these challenges, the advances in material design, interfacial modification, local environment control and reactor design have been further reviewed to benefit the industrial PEC seawater oxidation. Noticeably, we demonstrate engineered layered metal oxide electrodes and cell structures that enable powerful and stable seawater oxidation. We also outline and advise on the future direction in this area.
